topic.title: Plenty of errors around
topic.body: There seem  to be high amount of errors recently, which may or may not be related to my tor connection. Getting error on zeroboard, error on zeroid, and most of them "unknown" errors, with no visible explanation. Anyone experiencing similar?

2_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj.body:
> [hrc](#comment_1_1Gv5ZyDen9vqkAuHQHiiziAr9VHnC4gu85): Hello! I'm new. Could someone help me to test my new blog if it could be accessed? Thank you very much in advance!  http://127.0.0.1:43110/18G3oy6wg3esqkDKQhkPQGtRcL94PuK5Z9

its too big to pull by default (13MB>10MB)

> [dun](#comment_2_14nCEDo97Cx4VpSHwPytWvacPo29Y7FAbk): Why is this stickied? And who is able to sticky posts?

Let me guess: the admin of the service (ZeroTalk) decides who, what, how, when, why.

it doesn't and you'll never know. ;-)

@iusezeronet: Life's never been fair. Deal with it. 
But, on the bright side, we have messages like the one of @ekethis, a true gem of the results of the human evolution. No other species can do brain farts.

happy now? ;)

> [robxau](#comment_3_1QDPtMZr73ZewwEfjFJAh9vJG9r3Ztxvn2): "Content published to 1/1 peers." Yep, thanks! No messing around with router needed. :) Cheers again!

What basically happened is that you coerced me to lend my disk space and bandwidth to host your website. :-) Since most people are either too lazy or ignorant to go and delete a site they're not interested in you only need a few person to click on your site for whatever reason, and it's replicated, until the victims log off the virtual world. Like put one porn image on it and later you can remove the image and put up real content; the site will keep replicating.

#socialEngineering ;)

8_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj.body:
>> What happens if two people use the same keys to modify a site?
> Every content.json file is timestamped, the clients always accepts the newest one.

Yeah, and is there a compulsory time sync? What about fake clocks? Clock in the far future?

> [nofish](#comment_912_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): Clients only accept content.json timestamped local time + 1 day in the future. So in worst case you will be locked out for 1 day.

Sounds good, so I only have to write a script to timestamp T+23h any site I want to do a DoS?

Or generally speaking… I've seen the external security audit of [gocryptfs](https://defuse.ca/audits/gocryptfs.htm) which touched the general problem of _"We believe the reason these vulnerabilities exist is because gocryptfs doesn't have a clearly spelled-out threat model."_  Have anyone looked around the threat model of ZN and have examined the possibilities related?

Replying to myself: this reminds me to mention [vector clock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vector_clock) algorithm as the ordering in a completely distributed system.

(And what I was looking for was Google's TrueTime, but that's a completely different topic, really interesting nonetheless.)

> [nofish](#comment_913_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): If you have the private key for the site's address  then yes, you can block updates. (but in that case the site is already fucked up, since you can delete it)The user files are time stamped separately, so you can't cause any problem by that.

(I shall read through the whole architecture one day.) So on any user-input-processing site, like this one, I cannot send out updates which would block others from updating? Only myself? Not the database content or any dynamic files containing our user inputs?

Got a popleft: "This site requests permission: Merger:CDN [Grant]" but there is no explanation. This is a very bad practice, asking for a permission from the user without any explanation since it trains the user to blindly accept anything which is asked. That's the road to hell.
No, I haven't googled, since John Doe won't, either.
zeronet + ipfs? unite instead of diverge? was this point already raised? answered maybe?

> [7c4](#comment_8_12HT4jASzPG2B9vGbzvrbeyjw3jBUgqUfq): This site requests permission: Merger:ZeroMe [...]

It basically requests access to data stored in a seperate instance. It is really badly (un)documented.

> [kopyjane](#comment_11_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGNRLFcE): He's implying that sorting the languages into groups is another form of censorship, and they came to ZeroNet in order to avoid censorship.

That's bullshit, pardon my french. You say it's "censorship" if I kindly ask people not to pour trash onto the lawn I'm having picnic on? 

Using a language I cannot read is rubbish for me, it's not content, it's useless, it's an obstacle, a disturbance. What would be the point? If I allow it the alien speaker got no means of communication with me. Separating languages mean people who can communicate using that language actually can find it and use it, while people not understanding it don't have to suffer by browsing through gibberish.

4_1Np58q7bCfW7hmHuXvoYux3ij6M4Qecfb3.body:
> [peterjin](#comment_7_1Q7cRMcQk4MGUEPahLPcr7rUHxxrVsyBw3): The same idea. May be it is the last place of freedom speech..

Analysing (Layer7) firewalls don't care about the port. Only two kind of protocols are resilient to such adversaries:
* those which contain no protocol identifying properties at all (=look like random noise)
* those which look like a different, accepted protocol (web, dns, unless they are filtered, but then you forget internet altogether)

1_1Mpr8B1fRGBctzf7g9a6X1cb4WbQULH92N.body:
Incredibly high quality doesn't sound very credible ;-)

I have some methods in mind to do just that, but it'd involve very special microphones, specifically placed, and plenty of them, using some possibly insanely high sampling with large bit resolution, then some badass post-processing, and using some digital lossless format which would be able to handle that (flac seems to be able to handle 655 kHz sample rate and 32 bits per sample, but the usual en/decoders probably would choke and die). The result would be indeed incredible, apart from the fact that only about 15 people living on Earth would be able to tell the difference (possibly with serious measuring equipments), so it could be in the top 10 of Insanely Lot of Money and Time Wasted for Absolutely Nothing.

This book seems fun: https://books.google.hu/books?id=OYolDwAAQBAJ
And it looks like nobody really cared to create a 655 kHz sampled 32 bits (or rather 24 possibly due to lack of encoder support) test yet. We're far from incredible!

> [polar](#comment_6_13aB79mzuRLgDYzQthn9wzycjw77WyDXh6): Use BT Sync.

Or rather syncthing. ;-) But it's not quite fits the purpose. People are working on solutions, though.

11_1H5UJ7LneToGqYqJ9fbLnu1Ko2pxTpchof.body:
But you're acting ignorant, possibly because you are. Whatsapp is shit, right? And Telegram is cool, eh? You don't have the faintest idea what you're talking about. Why don't you start looking around _before_ you open your mouth?
And zeronet has almost nothing common with all the rest. 

But, to the others: Whatsapp security is pretty good, they only - possibly - steal metadata, but not the chat content, since they're using the same signal protocol as, surprise, Signal, which is the state of the art of chat encryption nowadays. Something similarly secure is Wire, and it's additionally much more anonymous than the former ones. OTOH Telegram normal chat is shit, same "security" as Google Hangout or basically whatever central service using TLS, which is absofuckinglutly nothing. Telegram secure chat is a wee bit better, but not that much better than it would earn to be called "useful". XMPP/OMEMO is quite good, but not widespread. That's about all, other are useless. If you want anon use Wire, if you want more security use Signal, if you don't care much about metadata (who do you contact) but want user friendliness use Whatsapp.

Zeronet is not a chat network, and it's not a peer-to-peer data exchange. At least not in that sense. And zeronet "chat" gets basically into a shared, displayed database. Not quite anon, not quite secure; not as bad as telegram, but I wouldn't use it for everyday secure communications. And to shatter the illusion of some: it can be easily filtered. Don't escape into a dream, reality is there even if you turn your head around.

> [iyogo887vyg87oy8](#comment_31_1H5UJ7LneToGqYqJ9fbLnu1Ko2pxTpchof): I asked why people latch on to the worst tech, not chat networks. 

Yet your examples were all chat networks. 

The question is pretty easy though: people prefer easy to use technology and they are oblivious about the real possibilities of privacy breach. Security almost always come with usage compromises, be that lack of speed, latency, storage efficiency or general hardness of use. People disprefer that to ease of use. And animated flying hearts and smiling cats.

> And I dont trust signal very much at all for various reasons 

Your choice. Must be very adventurous reasons I'm sure. I trust you being smarter than Snowden and the bunch of the security researchers out there. :-]

> and i think theres a reason pavel durov is rejecting fsb and being banned from iran, it cuz hes a badass dood

If "badass" imply "obstinate" and "headstrong" then he surely is, since when he decide to use bad crypto or crappy architecture there's no force in the world to convince him to let it go. But lots of people (who happen to be professionals on the field) isn't all extatic about his products due to the quite large amounts of security problems within them. It doesn't mean he's a wrong guy, it's just that there are smarter people around doing crypto than him. He is very good popularizing his stuff, and it's way better than nothing; it's just some people actually want much more than "better than nothing". You know, those who don't "latch on shitty tech". :-)

Which is ironic since it seems you're one of those "latching to worst tech". It may help you to be able to find the explanation though. :-D

> [rubit](#comment_10_18sV4LF2Q372BLkTJN5Z24HeRexQQscx1E): I think the reason, why poeple don't use more p2p/dencentralized tech is, because it's not user-friendly enough to them.which also means their friends are not on X, therefore they don't have a need to use it.

Exactly. When I was deep in testing I had, like, 12 chat clients installed, with various amounts of acquaintances reachable. The more unfriendly, obscure or unstable one was the less people were using it. Security-wise the best was tox - guess how many people are actually _able_ to use it.

> [iyogo887vyg87oy8](#comment_36_1H5UJ7LneToGqYqJ9fbLnu1Ko2pxTpchof): Facebook isn't primarily

I stand corrected. Not that it'd change my opinion.

> [severeburns](#comment_4_1CSDDARdrzUk9iXgx8bopdfRi3TsZmdPEP): To be honest, Zeronet is the most user-friendly decentralized platform I've ever used... Turn those Python scripts into Exes and anyone could use it

Basically _nobody_ uses it. We're just below the threshold of statistical error.

> [james007](#comment_48_1DiRWRFXcVgQQ75cXnAG2pyxxjGo2VaH5): Up until recently, it required using Gapps. In addition to that, you are required to have a phone number (bad for metadata), and to register (also bad for metadata), to use Signal's OWS server (bad for privacy). I appreciate Moxie's advances in encryption, but he fails entirely on anonymity and privacy. Would no longer recommend that app when we have Riot, Tox, and Tor Messenger at our disposal.

(Sidenote: you are making yourself looking ridiculous by answering using facts and knowledge, and thinking before writing. Use your emotions and second-hand newsbits! ;-))

Signal central reg is indeed not *anonymous*, but it's a known attribute of the service. (Gapps was due GMC activation but it's been removed IIRC.) It's the same for every centrally registered networks, which usually implies that _people_ can easily find their correspondents and the registration is super simple. Same goes with most of the chat out there. Moxie is a curious beast indeed. ;-)

Tox is the one I've just mentioned, and Wire is halfway there, since you can use email registration; it's obvious why Wire gets used and Tox isn't: the complete anonymity requires really uncomfortable handshake for first contact, not to mention that's its a way to easy to lose and that means starting the hi-there-where-are-you handshake all over again. :-) [Tor messenger was unusable last time I checked and Riot isn't existing just quite yet.]

All in all: the list above isn't the "worst tech". Depends on what you want to get.

> [blazar](#comment_8_1P1baCe1LLjror4CZjChWFy7D7cVWyPL83):  Telegram has fake encryption and every private conference in telegram is under control - admins can even read logs of private conferences in telegram. There is no privacy and security in telegram.

Ignorance is bliss.

> Tox is just half-dead project without competent developers

Indeed, it's a great bliss.

> RetroShare is ready and complete

My ass, friend. It's absolutely useless for chat, and in my experience, most of anything. We have tried it, worked, but it really had even lower impact than tox. It could be a good general sharing platform, but it... is not there yet.

> [realkittykate](#comment_5_17H8EGEoNF1z2AXFtXmBQJLHTmh7gMGzzS): I just use Facebook Messenger Lite to talk to friends and family.

If your phone is able to jail it, it may be not that scary shit, but if not it's requesting permission even to rape your little sister and the family dog.

> [fredbrach](#comment_2_1D73VppqMfxQKf8LXyfsXQgbVnxKJFiSDE): so stealing that file is stealing a user identity, possibly on the whole net.Anyway, I guess its not very hard to solve.

That's an interesting question, how do you *revoke* your identity once it's been mishandled, which happens more than one imagines.

> [iyogo887vyg87oy8](#comment_54_1H5UJ7LneToGqYqJ9fbLnu1Ko2pxTpchof): Lol you keep it safe in the first place. An analogy would be: if I lost hard cash (say a $10 note), how do you stop someone from spending it, I don't think you can

Well, well, you seem to have found the Secret of Eternal Life.
Which is "lol you don't die in the first place".

Next time maybe try a bit more practical approach. (Hint: almost everybody else uses a long passphrase to protect an identity, there are services providing secure revocation of identity, etc. Not that I'd say ZeroNet should do the same, all I say is that this should be thoroughly examined. You "lol" approach is not quite a reply to the question.)

> [fredbrach](#comment_3_1D73VppqMfxQKf8LXyfsXQgbVnxKJFiSDE): Your computer can get infected by a virus. That's how you got the file stolen.

Or I copy everything using a 0day (or, actually, anything between that and 365day unpatched stuff) exploit and cherry-pick what I want. Since zeronet filenames are pretty standard it's not that hard to create a script retrieving every zeronet config files.

> [cryptocoin](#comment_2_16eaG7Jf6Z3WSBaQakZrmYf35A4JSZnMth): What I see here is "too much script kids talk" than real world action. Code it and steal the credentials with your zeroday hacker skills first, than brag about it later.

Dunno about you, but I happen to administer a few hundred servers, and happen also to be contacted by people who should administer servers but they rather stuck at observing it hacked and call for help. You are very naïve if you think Linux is an unbreakable fortress: I see hacked Linux boxes all the time. Fortunately the hacks are more rare nowadays, thanks to the often forced updates, but still, huge amount of remote exploits around left unpatched by not really updated systems. And if you have a breach then _everything_ is up for sale. And it's not done by humans but scripts, lots of pre-written, downloadable, ready-to use scripts. Pretty fast scripts. Within ten minutes all the disks are scanned, and data is pulled in order of importance. Seen that "in the wild".
And I don't give a fuck about what you believe in, either about me, or anyone else, but I don't quite like that you hint ignorant people that they're safe because you say they are. I don't even waste the time to tell you to go and google phrases about accidental private key publishing, password sharing and so. Just shut up if you have nothing worthwhile to say. And ignore me, I'm just a script kiddie, as you have implied. I envy your professionality in various fields of information technology.
Have a nice day.

1512976214_18fU1ZPrTrUXVCYG4wDvk6fTB5ok4.body:
Because there's a whole world outside your backyard, friend. They do not speak Chinese, Urdu, Xu!, Basque or whatever local favourite language you have around. They speak their own tongue, which you don't get at all. So, as many times in human history, there's a common language these foreign people can use to communicate one another. And with you, possibly, if you are able to learn.

That's **English**, as of now.

> [esmein](#comment_3_1gJPRbL7puiekYd32rYVuCkELC43bCsY9):  If you speak mandarin or have an opportunity to learn it, I wouldn't shun the idea. 
I don't think "western" people would learn chinese no matter how "economically" intersting they believe they are. Politically they're pretty backwards, they always have been (at least for the last 3000 years or so). I'm not quite sure about the sustainability of their, um, economy. It may well happen that the people there get bored to be completely oppressed and start a really bloody civil war, then all will be very gone.
Or, and there's some pretty high writing and language barrier.

> [buizel](#comment_15_1NVRQ533fwKrZaRyP8joH2kk6gis2G7PVp): Well it makes sense to learn another major language.
"Major" as what? Largest population using it as mother tongue? Largest area covered by speakers? Largest vocabulary? Simplest grammar maybe?

So, there you are, by speakers:
1. Mandarin (955 million, but it's misleading since there are distinct dialects, and separating them results really small numbers)
2. Spanish (405m)
3. English (360)
4. Hindi (310, same goes as with mandarin)
5. Arabic (295)
6. Portugese (215)
7. Bengali (200)
8. Russian (155)
9. Japanese (125)
10. Punjabi (100)

Aye carramba! So are you going to learn Spanish or Hindi, soon? ;-)

> [tombombadildo](#comment_4_16AACVBLhoSY2jjGMtP7VKAEbjJUcKgQ1y): For most North Americans, Spanish would probably be far more useful than Chinese.

By number of speakers maybe, but it's not "globally relevant". Global movements usually involve electronics and trade, and spanish guys aren't near relevant in any of those. Of course until the time when the US government will consist only of people with spanish origins and the official US language will have become Spanish. Boy, I can hardly wait. :-P

> If Putin continues to enjoy success in destabilizing various Western alliances (NATO, the EU), Europeans ought to think about learning Russian. 😂

I have learned Russian. To be honest, the language itself is quite okay, pretty simple to learn and the writing system is rather straightforward (write as you speak, opposite of the really braindead English). The problem is that most of the people speaking it are either criminals or simpletons, and I mean it. There are really nice, smart Russian speaking people, and we love all of that 200 000 or so.... :-)

But I really do not look forward to those times. Learning Russian outside Russia have been exclusively driven by political agenda in tha last 50+ years. If you have to learn it, you can be sure you're fucked.

> [lonelyreader](#comment_4_1PyrAjbZiHyfW7jSWeUpDPSeMU7sAJ5HSs): 
> English can be displayed on every machine, some machine cannot display UTF-8 (or at least some text-based browser on the ascii console )

You should shove it up your ass, then. ;-) Most OS in the last 10 years are able to use unicode consoles and GUIs, and most free fonts cover basic planes, too. 
And, obviously, the problem usually is not that we don't _see_ the glyphs but that we can't make out their fucking meaning. :-)

> [lonelyreader](#comment_5_1PyrAjbZiHyfW7jSWeUpDPSeMU7sAJ5HSs): typo, at least in programming languages

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-English-based_programming_languages

:-D

> [m00plicate](#comment_20_12pqz164272L8bYB9UA2enxr92boTWBpfd): To everyone shitting on historical (as opposed to phonetic) spelling in English: Historical spelling has several advantages over phonetic spelling. 

I cannot prove you're wrong, it just feels like it. You may or may not be aware that English is two language to learn: one written and one pronounced. They have little relation to one another. I would say no matter how many funky "positive" examples you try to pull up your sleeve it's all just irrelevant minorities to the huge disadvantage of a spelling distanced from the pronounciation. I don't know how many languages you speak, I happen to know a few, and possibly English spelling is the worst of all. And, as I said, probably Russian is one of the nicest spelling-wise (but I believe sanskrit would even better, it's also using a phonologically systematic writing system, beyond closely following the spoken language).

So,  what I mean is, when I need a language to communicate I don't give a flying fuck how does it support language history, ancient usage or local accents. These are nice to have, unless they block the primary usage which is clear, simple, effective communication. In case of English they very much obstruct learning and communication.

(And it's even worse, as I heard, since plenty of people with english as mother tongue haven't learnt grammar, they just try to get along mimicking what others do. I've learnt some grammar most of the US people can't even reproduce. Okay, accepted, apart from my continuous errors, I haven't said I'm perfect. :-))

> [buizel](#comment_18_1NVRQ533fwKrZaRyP8joH2kk6gis2G7PVp): Hey I love brain dead English with it's bullshit rules and disregard for rules and not pronouncing words as they are it's what makes it uniqueXD

vel yes, we kan make it junik by simplify speling. :-)

> [krixano](#comment_248_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): And everyone learns grammar,

I can only relay what my friends and acquaintances have told me: neither in Britain nor in the US they have been taught what we in Europe learn as "grammar". Granted, they have been taught some really basic stuff, but far from what we have here around in our mother tongue. But maybe they were special, or exceptions, or lived in weird places, or forgot about it, whatever. I'm not them. They seemed pretty sure what they were talking about.

My experience showed that sometimes I've been using a tense my correspondent were not able to construct, and had vague image about its meaning, and he's been living in the US since T+0. It was some very weird experience.

And I'm aware that English pronunciation have rules, I've been programmed some speech synth on C=64, and had to find the rules by myself, but if you look at Russian you'll see what I mean by "unreasonably diverted from spoken language". You possibly know the poem titled "The Chaos" by Dr. Gerard Nolst Trenité, but if you wouldn't, check it up.

> [schlump](#comment_2_1KXM1dgKoGE85L7Z5r7uyxmG1GcZLBh6TC): Also @flappyearz, are you arguing FOR English as a lingua franca, or against it?
It's beyond arguments: it is the lingua franca as of now. It's not a bad language, a funny mixture of frank, scandinavian (or norse), french and eventually latin, possibly not much worse than German or Swedish. The structure (analytic constructions) are much easier to learn than agglutination, probably this helps the native US speakers to stay alive who are not the brightest persons on Earth. :-P It's using latin alphabet so writing is easy to learn for the western people (or, actually, nearly anyone but the Indian and Chinese). It'll do.

I'm not a fan on slavic people, but their language is okay. Spanish and Italian is not that bad either but I'm not familar with the word stems, so lots of work to learn. But all of these are vastly easier for me to learn than some weirdo-looking one like Japanese, Chinese or, say, Urdu. Not to mention their absolutely wasted writing systems. (Hmm, to be honest, devanagari is one I really like, but not Chinese or Japanese.) And obviously the total dictatoric and oppressive  Chinese political system doesn't help to get to like it more. (English is hard to judge, since it's spoken in both the Land of the Braindead [US] and the Medieval Empire (GB). Latter is quite likeable.)

> [krixano](#comment_253_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): So, I wrote out a lot of stuff, but I accidentally closed the tab, so I'm not rewriting all of it.
Oh. Okay. This is not the best medium to have a serious discussion, anyway.

>First, You are putting a lot of weight on these so called "acquaintances". Try some research - you can clearly see that English Grammar is taught in schools in Britain, it's part of a new curriculum they started in 2015.

You really must be kidding. So I'm wrong since it's part of the curriculum since, uh, two years?

To be honest, the long discussions about language have happened a while ago, I guess it's been almost a decade ago. What I say isn't about the current snapshot of the world, it was about people who were grown up there, and speak English as their first language; and these people were all well educated and several magnitudes more fluent and knowledgeable than my poor self. Advising me to research isn't quite fair: I am in no position to know what's been changed recently, and I have no means to research the linguistical knowledge of the population of the age group 30-99. You state that real grammar have been taught for the last 40+ years, I have heard it the other way, and I have no means to prove me right or you wrong. 

> I doubt this very much. I think you are lying so hard about this.
Oh that's nice. What's the point arguing with a _liar_, then, friend? (Just for the record: I am not.)

> And I do hope you aren't talking about some tense in another language that doesn't exist in English (not all languages have the same tenses).
No. I look up the terminus technicus, stand by.
Thanks for waiting. So it's called "verb tense", and there are stuff like "future perfect continuous" or "conditional tenses".  Something like this: https://www.ef.com/english-resources/english-grammar/verbs/

> I also hope that you aren't talking about them not knowing the technical terms of these tenses.
No, that would be unfair. 

>Sorry if I don't believe you considering the main mistakes in your English have been how you construct verb phrases/tenses.
As this one surely was. I already tried to mention that my grammar is crap and I ain't no native speaker, and my level of English is absolutely not the best possible, and I also make quite a few typos and lazy to read it over and fix. It doesn't change my _knowledge_ though, and since I am pretty interested in linguistics for the last few decades we may say that I have some vague ideas what I am talking about. 

What languages do *you* speak? On what level?

> What is really pissing me off is how you are looking down on native English speakers because, as you suppose, they don't learn grammar in schools. 
You are very mistaken here, since this is really far from my opinion. I really love to hear British speakers (and I don't mean TV talking heads but simple, everyday British/English people) since they use the language a way I really like. They haven't got much knowledge about the grammar and the grammatical rules but that doesn't influence their absolutely proper language usage. My opinion is not about their inferiority or superiority, but about the language as being one running much more uncontrolled than lots of other languages around, where people are taught in elementary schools the basic rules and they are aware (on some subconscious level) that there are rules and they kind of keep them working, while English feels like mutating much more than it'd be optimal. This is just a feeling from an outsider, I really cannot even tell you why I have this feeling.

> Obviously they have learned the grammar otherwise they would not know how to speak the language. 
This is, my friend, a total bullshit. I speak languages without knowing the grammatical rules, just based on the patterns I've learned and the phrases people most often use. Obviously grammar stick after a while, but not as a science but an instinctional mindset. Most of the speakers probably don't have the faintest idea about linguistics as a science, and its rules or definitions. (Again, this is not my peer-reviewed PhD but my opinion.)

>It seems you are also making the assumption that learning grammar in schools is actually effective/useful. 
Yes.

>However, there have been research studies that say otherwise.
Otherwise? You learn grammar and you start speaking worse? Can I doubt this "proof" please?

> Also, I'm not completely sure if you know what grammar actually is. 
Obviously. You seem to be a pretty unsure person.

> The grammar of a language encompasses the majority of the language, including its sounds (Phonology), word-structure/building (Morphology), word-order/sentence-structure (Syntax), word-meanings (Semantics), and everything else (Pragmatics).
My original comments were, if you're into scientifical linguistics, about phonology, and this debate was about morphology, morphophonology, syntax and orthography (in case of Chinese). But even if these are all so nice words, I would rather prefer to talk about "grammar", and let the context sort out what I mean. 

As closing: don't act like a minority and don't get offended. I either think you're all shit or think that you're all just humans like me. Either case it's really pointless to prove you're not something you aren't. Oh, and calling names is a different way of debate than debating the opinions.

> [schlump](#comment_2_1KXM1dgKoGE85L7Z5r7uyxmG1GcZLBh6TC): You know what other languages have a writing system unrelated to its spoken form? Chinese languages. 
Tonality is absolutely weird for me. Then I've looked into the origins and structure of their writing system, and while it's a really interesting topic it's also absolutely helping the mental image that the writing system should be avoided as much as possible for any real language use. :-)

But, apart from all those, look up there, in the top line:

Forums: English · Dansk · Español · Français · Deutsch · Magyar · Italiano · Polski · Português · Québec · Русский · Українська · 中文论坛

Interesting mixture of languges. Still I wonder what would @swordair say if s/he had to use Ukraininan or Hungarian instead of English. :-P
